key_mistakes.reason: This move is a passive choice in the opening, allowing White to establish a strong center with d4. Playing e5 would contest the center more actively.
Missing a tactical opportunity to gain an advantage with a check.
This move allows Black to consolidate and develop without pressure. Capturing the Knight on c6 would have doubled Black's pawns and weakened their position.
Ignoring a tactical opportunity to harass White's king position.
This move weakens the pawn structure and doesn't contribute to piece activity. Developing the knight would increase control over the center and connect the rooks.
This move allows Black to regain control over the position and misses a chance to put pressure on Black's king.
This move unnecessarily advances the pawn, missing a chance to put the king in check and improve the knight position.

recommendations: In the Caro-Kann Defense, aim to control the center with pawn moves and piece development.
Look for tactical opportunities, especially when the opponent's king is exposed.
Maintain a solid pawn structure to avoid creating weaknesses.
Develop your pieces actively and ensure they coordinate well, especially in the middle game.
